The '''trigonometry of a tetrahedron'''<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = The Trigonometry of the Tetrahedron|jstor = 3603090|journal = The Mathematical Gazette|date = 1902-03-01|pages = 149–158|volume = 2|issue = 32|doi = 10.2307/3603090|first = G.|last = Richardson}}</ref> explains the relationships between the [[length]]s and various types of [[angle]]s of a general [[tetrahedron]].

== Trigonometric quantities ==

=== Classical trigonometric quantities ===
The following are trigonometric quantities generally associated to a general tetrahedron:
* The 6 ''edge lengths'' - associated to the six edges of the tetrahedron.
* The 12 ''face angles'' - there are three of them for each of the four faces of the tetrahedron.
* The 6 ''[[dihedral angle]]s'' - associated to the six edges of the tetrahedron, since any two faces of the tetrahedron are connected by an edge.
* The 4 ''[[solid angle]]s'' - associated to each point of the tetrahedron.
Let <math>X = \overline{P_1P_2P_3P_4}</math> be a general tetrahedron, where <math>P_1,P_2,P_3,P_4</math> are arbitrary points in [[Three-dimensional space (mathematics)|three-dimensional space]].

Furthermore, let <math>e_{ij}</math> be the edge that joins <math>P_{i}</math> and <math>P_{j}</math> and let <math>F_{i}</math> be the face of the tetrahedron opposite the point <math>P_{i}</math>; in other words:
* <math>e_{ij}=\overline{P_iP_j}</math>
* <math>F_i = \overline{P_jP_kP_l}</math>
where <math>i,j,k,l \in \{1,2,3,4\}</math> and <math>i \neq j \neq k \neq l</math>.

Define the following quantities:
* <math>d_{ij}</math> = the length of the edge <math>e_{ij}</math>
* <math>\alpha_{i,j}</math> = the angle spread at the point <math>P_i</math> on the face <math>F_{j}</math>
* <math>\theta_{ij}</math> = the dihedral angle between two faces adjacent to the edge <math>e_{ij}</math>
* <math>\Omega_i</math> = the solid angle at the point <math>P_i</math>

=== Area and volume ===
Let <math>\Delta_i</math> be the [[area]] of the face <math>F_i</math>. Such area may be calculated by [[Heron's formula]] (if all three edge lengths are known):

: <math>\Delta_i = \sqrt{\frac{(d_{jk}+d_{jl}+d_{kl})(-d_{jk}+d_{jl}+d_{kl})(d_{jk}-d_{jl}+d_{kl})(d_{jk}+d_{jl}-d_{kl})}{16}}</math>

or by the following formula (if an angle and two corresponding edges are known):

: <math>\Delta_i = \frac{1}{2}d_{jk} d_{jl}\sin\alpha_{j,i}</math>

Let <math>h_i</math> be the [[Altitude (triangle)|altitude]] from the point <math>P_{i}</math> to the face <math>F_{i}</math>. The [[volume]] <math>V</math> of the tetrahedron <math>X
</math> is given by the following formula: <math display="block">V = \frac{1}{3}\Delta_{i}h_{i}</math>It satisfies the following relation:<ref>{{Cite book|title = 100 Great Problems of Elementary Mathematics|url = https://www.amazon.com/Great-Problems-Elementary-Mathematics-Dover/dp/0486613488|publisher = Dover Publications|date = 1965-06-01|location = New York|isbn = 9780486613482}}</ref>

: <math>288V^2 = \begin{vmatrix} 2Q_{12} & Q_{12}+Q_{13}-Q_{23} & Q_{12}+Q_{14}-Q_{24} \\ Q_{12}+Q_{13}-Q_{23} & 2Q_{13} & Q_{13}+Q_{14}-Q_{34} \\ Q_{12}+Q_{14}-Q_{24} & Q_{13}+Q_{14}-Q_{34} & 2Q_{14} \end{vmatrix}</math>
where <math>Q_{ij} = d_{ij}^2</math> are the quadrances (length squared) of the edges.

== Basic statements of trigonometry ==

=== Affine triangle ===
Take the face <math>F_{i}</math>; the edges will have lengths <math>d_{jk},d_{jl},d_{kl}</math> and the respective opposite angles are given by <math>\alpha_{l,i},\alpha_{k,i},\alpha_{j,i}</math>.

The usual laws for [[trigonometry|planar trigonometry]] of a triangle hold for this triangle.

=== Projective triangle ===
Consider the [[Spherical triangle|projective (spherical) triangle]] at the point <math>P_i</math>; the vertices of this projective triangle are the three lines that join <math>P_i</math> with the other three vertices of the tetrahedron. The edges will have spherical lengths <math>\alpha_{i,j},\alpha_{i,k},\alpha_{i,l}</math> and the respective opposite spherical angles are given by <math>\theta_{ij},\theta_{ik},\theta_{il}</math>.

The usual laws for [[spherical trigonometry]] hold for this projective triangle.

== Laws of trigonometry for the tetrahedron ==

===Alternating sines theorem===
Take the tetrahedron <math>X</math>, and consider the point <math>P_i</math> as an apex. The Alternating sines theorem is given by the following identity:<math display="block">\sin(\alpha_{j,l})\sin(\alpha_{k,j})\sin(\alpha_{l,k}) = \sin(\alpha_{j,k})\sin(\alpha_{k,l})\sin(\alpha_{l,j})</math>One may view the two sides of this identity as corresponding to clockwise and counterclockwise orientations of the surface.

==== The space of all shapes of tetrahedra ====
[[Image:tetra.png|248px]]

Putting any of the four vertices in the role of ''O'' yields four such identities, but at most three of them are independent; if the "clockwise" sides of three of the four identities are multiplied and the product is inferred to be equal to the product of the "counterclockwise" sides of the same three identities, and then common factors are cancelled from both sides, the result is the fourth identity.

Three angles are the angles of some triangle if and only if their sum is 180° (π radians). What condition on 12 angles is necessary and sufficient for them to be the 12 angles of some tetrahedron? Clearly the sum of the angles of any side of the tetrahedron must be 180°. Since there are four such triangles, there are four such constraints on sums of angles, and the number of [[Degrees of freedom (statistics)|degrees of freedom]] is thereby reduced from 12 to 8. The four relations given by the [[Law of sines|sine law]] further reduce the number of degrees of freedom, from 8 down to not 4 but 5, since the fourth constraint is not independent of the first three. Thus the space of all shapes of tetrahedra is 5-dimensional.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=Is There a "Most Chiral Tetrahedron"? |first1=André |last1=Rassat |first2=Patrick W. |last2=Fowler |journal=Chemistry: A European Journal |volume=10 |issue=24 |pages=6575–6580 |year=2004 |doi=10.1002/chem.200400869 |postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref>

=== Law of sines for the tetrahedron ===
See: [[Law of sines#Higher dimensions|Law of sines]]

=== Law of cosines for the tetrahedron ===
The [[Law of cosines|law of cosines for the tetrahedron]]<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = The law of cosines in a tetrahedron|last = Lee|first = Jung Rye|date = June 1997|journal = J. Korea. Soc. Math. Educ. Ser. B: Pure Appl. Math.|doi = |pmid = |volume = 4|issn = 1226-0657|issue = 1|pages = 1–6}}</ref> relates the areas of each face of the tetrahedron and the dihedral angles about a point. It is given by the following identity:

: <math>\Delta_i^2 = \Delta_j^2 + \Delta_k^2 + \Delta_l^2 - 2(\Delta_{j}\Delta_{k}\cos\theta_{il} + \Delta_j \Delta_l \cos\theta_{ik}+\Delta_k \Delta_l \cos\theta_{ij})</math>

=== Relationship between dihedral angles of tetrahedron ===
Take the general tetrahedron <math>X</math> and project the faces <math>F_i,F_j,F_k</math> onto the plane with the face <math>F_l</math>. Let <math>c_{ij} = \cos\theta_{ij}</math>.

Then the area of the face <math>F_l</math> is given by the sum of the projected areas, as follows:<math display="block">\Delta_l = \Delta_ic_{jk} + \Delta_jc_{ik} + \Delta_kc_{ij}</math>By substitution of <math>i,j,k,l \in \{1,2,3,4\}</math> with each of the four faces of the tetrahedron, one obtains the following homogeneous system of linear equations:<math display="block">\begin{cases}
-\Delta_1 + \Delta_2c_{34} + \Delta_3c_{24} + \Delta_4c_{23} = 0 \\ 
\Delta_1c_{34} - \Delta_2 + \Delta_3c_{14} + \Delta_4c_{13} = 0\\ 
\Delta_1c_{24} + \Delta_2c_{14} - \Delta_3 + \Delta_4c_{12} = 0\\
\Delta_1c_{23} + \Delta_2c_{13} + \Delta_3c_{12} - \Delta_4 = 0
\end{cases}</math>This homogeneous system will have solutions precisely when: <math display="block">\begin{vmatrix} 
-1 & c_{34} & c_{24} & c_{23} \\ 
c_{34} & -1 & c_{14} & c_{13} \\ 
c_{24} & c_{14} & -1 & c_{12} \\ 
c_{23} & c_{13} & c_{12} & -1
\end{vmatrix}
= 0</math>By expanding this determinant, one obtains the relationship between the dihedral angles of the tetrahedron,<ref name=":0" /> as follows: <math display="block">1-\sum_{1 \leq i < j \leq 4}c^{2}_{ij}+\sum_{j=2\atop k\neq l\neq j}^{4}c^{2}_{1j}c^{2}_{kl}
= 2\left(\sum_{i=1\atop j\neq k\neq l\neq i}^{4}c_{ij}c_{ik}c_{il}+\sum_{2\leq j<k\leq 4\atop l\neq j,k}c_{1j}c_{1k}c_{jl}c_{kl}\right)
</math>

=== Skew distances between edges of tetrahedron ===
Take the general tetrahedron <math>X</math> and let <math>P_{ij}</math> be the point on the edge <math>e_{ij}</math> and <math>P_{kl}</math> be the point on the edge <math>e_{kl}</math> such that the line segment <math>\overline{P_{ij}P_{kl}}</math> is perpendicular to both <math>e_{ij}</math> & <math>e_{kl}</math>. Let <math>R_{ij}</math> be the length of the line segment <math>\overline{P_{ij}P_{kl}}</math>.

To find <math>R_{ij}</math>:<ref name=":0" />

First, construct a line through <math>P_{k}</math> parallel to <math>e_{il}</math> and another line through <math>P_{i}</math> parallel to <math>e_{kl}</math>. Let <math>O</math> be the intersection of these two lines. Join the points <math>O</math> and <math>P_{j}</math>. By construction, <math>\overline{OP_iP_lP_k}</math> is a parallelogram and thus <math>\overline{OP_kP_i}</math> and <math>\overline{OP_lP_i}</math> are congruent triangles. Thus, the tetrahedron <math>X</math> and <math>Y = \overline{OP_iP_jP_k}</math> are equal in volume.

As a consequence, the quantity <math>R_{ij}</math> is equal to the altitude from the point <math>P_{k}</math> to the face <math>\overline{OP_iP_j}</math> of the tetrahedron <math>Y</math>; this is shown by translation of the line segment <math>\overline{P_{ij}P_{kl}}</math>.

By the volume formula, the tetrahedron <math>Y</math> satisfies the following relation: <math display="block">3V = R_{ij} \times \Delta(\overline{OP_iP_j})</math>where <math>\Delta(\overline{OP_iP_j})</math> is the area of the triangle <math>\overline{OP_iP_j}</math>. Since the length of the line segment <math>\overline{OP_i}</math> is equal to <math>d_{kl}</math> (as <math>\overline{OP_iP_lP_k}</math> is a parallelogram): <math display="block">\Delta(\overline{OP_iP_j}) = \frac{1}{2}d_{ij}d_{kl}\sin\lambda</math>where <math>\lambda = \angle OP_iP_j</math>. Thus, the previous relation becomes: <math display="block">6V = R_{ij}d_{ij}d_{kl}\sin\lambda</math>To obtain <math>\sin\lambda</math>, consider two spherical triangles: 
# Take the spherical triangle of the tetrahedron <math>X</math> at the point <math>P_i</math>; it will have sides <math>\alpha_{i,j},\alpha_{i,k},\alpha_{i,l}</math> and opposite angles <math>\theta_{ij},\theta_{ik},\theta_{il}</math>. By the spherical law of cosines:<math display="block">\cos\alpha_{i,k} = \cos\alpha_{i,j}\cos\alpha_{i,l}+\sin\alpha_{i,j}\sin\alpha_{i,l}\cos\theta_{ik}</math> 
# Take the spherical triangle of the tetrahedron <math>X</math> at the point <math>P_i</math>. The sides are given by <math>\alpha_{i,l},\alpha_{k,j},\lambda</math> and the only known opposite angle is that of <math>\lambda</math>, given by <math>\pi - \theta_{ik}</math>. By the spherical law of cosines:<math display="block">\cos\lambda = \cos\alpha_{i,l}\cos\alpha_{k,j}-\sin\alpha_{i,l}\sin\alpha_{k,j}\cos\theta_{ik}</math> 
Combining the two equations gives the following result:<math display="block">\cos\alpha_{i,k}\sin\alpha_{k,j} + \cos\lambda\sin\alpha_{i,j}
= \cos\alpha_{i,l}\left(\cos\alpha_{i,j}\sin\alpha_{k,j} + \sin\alpha_{i,j}\cos\alpha_{k,j}\right)
=\cos\alpha_{i,l}\sin\alpha_{l,j}</math>

Making <math>\cos\lambda</math> the subject:<math display="block">\cos\lambda = \cos\alpha_{i,l}\frac{\sin\alpha_{l,j}}{\sin\alpha_{i,j}} - \cos\alpha_{i,k}\frac{\sin\alpha_{k,j}}{\sin\alpha_{i,j}}</math>Thus, using the cosine law and some basic trigonometry:<math display="block">\cos\lambda 
= \frac{d_{ij}^2+d_{ik}^2-d_{jk}^2}{2d_{ij}d_{ik}}\frac{d_{ik}}{d_{kl}} 
- \frac{d_{ij}^2+d_{il}^2-d_{jl}^2}{2d_{ij}d_{il}}\frac{d_{il}}{d_{kl}}
= \frac{d_{ik}^2+d_{jl}^2-d_{il}^2-d_{jk}^2}{2d_{ij}d_{kl}}</math>Thus:<math display="block">\sin\lambda = \sqrt{1-\left(\frac{d_{ik}^2+d_{jl}^2-d_{il}^2-d_{jk}^2}{2d_{ij}d_{kl}}\right)^2}
=\frac{\sqrt{4d_{ij}^2d_{kl}^2-(d_{ik}^2+d_{jl}^2-d_{il}^2-d_{jk}^2)^2}}{2d_{ij}d_{kl}}</math>So:<math display="block">R_{ij} = \frac{12V}{\sqrt{4d_{ij}^2d_{kl}^2-(d_{ik}^2+d_{jl}^2-d_{il}^2-d_{jk}^2)^2}}</math><math>R_{ik}</math> and <math>R_{il}</math> are obtained by permutation of the edge lengths.

Note that the denominator is a re-formulation of the [[Bretschneider's formula|Bretschneider-von Staudt formula]], which evaluates the area of a general convex quadrilateral.

pages.title: Elliptic function
pages.text:
In [[complex analysis]], an '''elliptic function''' is a [[meromorphic function]] that is [[periodic function|periodic]] in two directions. Just as a periodic function of a real variable is defined by its values on an interval, an elliptic function is determined by its values on a [[fundamental parallelogram (complex analysis)|fundamental parallelogram]], which then repeat in a [[lattice (group)|lattice]]. Such a [[doubly periodic function]] cannot be [[Holomorphic function|holomorphic]], as it would then be a [[bounded function|bounded]] [[entire function]], and by [[Liouville's theorem (complex analysis)|Liouville's theorem]] every such function must be constant. In fact, an elliptic function must have at least two [[pole (complex analysis)|poles]] (counting multiplicity) in a fundamental parallelogram, as it is easy to show using the periodicity that a [[contour integral]] around its boundary must vanish, implying that the [[residue theorem|residues]] of all simple poles must cancel.

Historically, elliptic functions were first discovered by [[Niels Henrik Abel]] as [[inverse function]]s of [[elliptic integral]]s, and their theory was improved by [[Carl Gustav Jacobi]]; these in turn were studied in connection with the problem of the [[arc length]] of an [[ellipse]], whence the name derives. [[Jacobi's elliptic functions]] have found numerous applications in physics, and were used by Jacobi to prove some results in elementary number theory. A more complete study of elliptic functions was later undertaken by [[Karl Weierstrass]], who found a simple elliptic function in terms of which all the others could be expressed. Besides their practical use in the evaluation of integrals and the explicit solution of certain differential equations, they have deep connections with [[elliptic curve]]s and [[modular form]]s.

==Definition==
Formally, an elliptic function is a function {{mvar|f}} meromorphic on {{math|'''ℂ'''}} for which there exist two non-zero complex numbers {{math|''ω''<sub>1</sub>}} and {{math|''ω''<sub>2</sub>}} with {{math|{{sfrac|''ω''<sub>1</sub>|''ω''<sub>2</sub>}} ∉ '''ℝ'''}}, such that {{math|''f''(''z'') {{=}} ''f''(''z'' + ''ω''<sub>1</sub>)}} and {{math|''f''(''z'') {{=}} ''f''(''z'' + ''ω''<sub>2</sub>)}} for all {{math|''z'' ∈ '''ℂ'''}}.

Denoting the "lattice of periods" by {{math|Λ {{=}} {''mω''<sub>1</sub> + ''nω''<sub>2</sub> {{!}} ''m'', ''n'' ∈ '''ℤ'''}|}}, it follows that {{math|''f''(''z'') {{=}} ''f''(''z'' + ''ω'')}} for all {{math|''ω'' ∈ Λ}}.

There are two families of 'canonical' elliptic functions: those of Jacobi and those of Weierstrass. Although Jacobi's elliptic functions are older and more directly relevant to applications, modern authors mostly follow Weierstrass when presenting the elementary theory, because his [[Weierstrass's elliptic functions|functions]] are simpler,{{Citation needed|date=December 2018}} and any elliptic function can be expressed in terms of them.

==Weierstrass' elliptic functions==
{{Main|Weierstrass elliptic function}}

With the definition of elliptic functions given above (which is due to Weierstrass) the Weierstrass elliptic function {{math|℘(''z'')}} is constructed in the most obvious way: given a lattice {{math|Λ}} as above, put

: <math>\wp(z)=\frac{1}{z^2}+\sum_{\omega\in\Lambda\smallsetminus\left\{ 0\right\} }\left(\frac{1}{(z-\omega)^2}-\frac{1}{\omega^2}\right)</math>

This function is clearly invariant with respect to the transformation {{math|''z'' ↦ ''z'' + ''ω''}} for any {{math|''ω'' ∈ Λ}}. The addition of the {{math|−{{sfrac|1|''ω''<sup>2</sup>}}}} terms is necessary to make the sum converge. The technical condition to ensure that an infinite sum such as this converges to a meromorphic function is that on any compact set, after omitting the finitely many terms having poles in that set, the remaining series converges [[normal convergence|normally]]. On any compact disk defined by {{math|{{abs|''z''}} ≤ ''R''}}, and for any {{math|{{abs|''ω''}} > 2''R''}}, one has

: <math>\left|\frac{1}{\left(z-\omega\right)^2}-\frac{1}{\omega^2}\right|=\left|\frac{2\omega z-z^2}{\omega^2(\omega-z)^2}\right|=\left|\frac{z\left(2-\frac{z}{\omega}\right)}{\omega^3\left(1-\frac{z}{\omega}\right)^2}\right|\leq\frac{10 R}{\left|\omega\right|^3}</math>

and it can be shown that the sum

: <math>\sum_{\omega\neq0}\frac{1}{\left|\omega\right|^3}</math>

converges regardless of {{math|Λ}}.<ref name="Cartan">{{cite book | title=Elementary Theory of Analytic Functions of One or Several Complex Variables | publisher=Dover Publications| last=Cartan | first=Henri | authorlink=Henri Cartan | year=1995 | pages=154 | isbn=9780486685434}}</ref>

By writing {{math|℘}} as a [[Laurent series]] and explicitly comparing terms, one may verify that it satisfies the relation

: <math>\bigl(\wp'(z)\bigr)^2=4\bigl(\wp(z)\bigr)^3-g_2 \wp(z)-g_3</math>

where

: <math>g_2=60\sum_{\omega\in\Lambda\smallsetminus\left\{ 0\right\} }\frac{1}{\omega^4}</math>

and

: <math>g_3=140\sum_{\omega\in\Lambda\smallsetminus\left\{ 0\right\} }\frac{1}{\omega^6}.</math>

This means that the pair {{math|(℘,℘′)}} parametrize an elliptic curve.

The functions {{math|℘}} take different forms depending on {{math|Λ}}, and a rich theory is developed when one allows {{math|Λ}} to vary. To this effect, put {{math|''ω''<sub>1</sub> {{=}} 1}} and {{math|''ω''<sub>2</sub> {{=}} ''τ''}}, with {{math|Im(''τ'') > 0}}. (After a rotation and a scaling factor, any lattice may be put in this form.)

A holomorphic function in the upper half plane {{math|''H'' {{=}} {''z'' ∈ '''ℂ''' {{!}} Im(''z'') > 0}|}} which is invariant under [[linear fractional transformation]]s with integer coefficients and determinant 1 is called a [[modular function]]. That is, a holomorphic function {{math|''h'' : ''H'' → '''ℂ'''}} is a modular function if

: <math>h\left(\tau\right)=h\left(\frac{a\tau+b}{c\tau+d}\right)\quad \text{for all }\left(\begin{matrix}a & c\\b & d\end{matrix}\right)\in \text{SL}_2(\mathbb{Z})</math>.

One such function is [[j-invariant|Klein's {{math|''j''}}-invariant]], defined by

: <math>j\left(\tau\right)=\frac{1728g_2^3}{g_2^3-27g_3^2}</math>

where {{math|''g''<sub>2</sub>}} and {{math|''g''<sub>3</sub>}} are as above.

==Jacobi's elliptic functions==
{{Main|Jacobi elliptic functions}}
{{Main|Theta function}}

[[Image:JacobiFunctionAbstract.png|width322px|thumb|Auxiliary rectangle construction]]
There are twelve Jacobian elliptic functions. Each of the twelve corresponds to an arrow drawn from one corner of a rectangle to another.  The corners of the rectangle are labeled, by convention, {{math|s}}, {{math|c}}, {{math|d}} and {{math|n}}. The rectangle is understood to be lying on the [[complex plane]], so that {{math|s}} is at the origin, {{math|c}} is at the point {{mvar|K}} on the real axis, {{math|d}} is at the point {{math|''K'' + ''iK''′}} and {{math|n}} is at point {{math|''iK''′}} on the imaginary axis.  The numbers {{mvar|K}} and {{math|''K''′}} are called the [[quarter period]]s.  The twelve Jacobian elliptic functions are then {{math|pq}}, where {{math|p}} and {{math|q}} are two different letters in {{math|s, c, d, n}}.

The Jacobian elliptic functions are then the unique doubly periodic, [[meromorphic]] functions satisfying the following three properties:
* There is a simple zero at the corner {{math|p}}, and a simple pole at the corner {{math|q}}.
* The step from {{math|p}} to {{math|q}} is equal to half the period of the function {{math|pq ''u''}}; that is, the function {{math|pq ''u''}} is periodic in the direction {{math|pq}}, with the period being twice the distance from {{math|p}} to {{math|q}}.  The function {{math|pq ''u''}} is also periodic in the other two directions, with a period such that the distance from {{math|p}} to one of the other corners is a quarter period.
* If the function {{math|pq ''u''}} is expanded in terms of {{mvar|u}} at one of the corners, the leading term in the expansion has a coefficient of 1.  In other words, the leading term of the expansion of {{math|pq ''u''}} at the corner {{math|p}} is {{mvar|u}}; the leading term of the expansion at the corner {{math|q}} is {{math|{{sfrac|1|''u''}}}}, and the leading term of an expansion at the other two corners is 1.

More generally, there is no need to impose a rectangle; a parallelogram will do. However, if {{mvar|K}} and {{math|''iK''′}} are kept on the real and imaginary axis, respectively, then the Jacobi elliptic functions {{math|pq ''u''}} will be real functions when {{mvar|u}} is real.

==Abel's elliptic functions==
{{Main|Abel elliptic functions}}

[[Elliptic integral]]s had been studied in great detail by [[Adrien Marie Legendre|Legendre]] who had reduced them to three fundamental types. Abel wrote an integral of the first kind as

: <math> u =  \int_0^x \frac{dt}{\sqrt{\left(1 - c^2 t^2\right)\left(1 + e^2 t^2\right)}} </math>

where {{mvar|c}} and {{mvar|e}} are two parameters.<ref name = Gray> J. Gray, ''The Real and the Complex: A History of Analysis in the 19th Century'', Springer, Heidelberg (2015). {{isbn|978-3-319-23714-5}}.</ref> This is a generalization of the integral which gives the [[arc length]] of the [[lemniscate]] corresponding to the special values {{math|''c'' {{=}} ''e'' {{=}} 1}} and investigated by [[Carl Friedrich Gauss]]. The arc length of the circle would result from setting {{math|''c'' {{=}} 1}} and {{math|''e'' {{=}} 0}}.

The value {{mvar|u}} of the integral is an increasing function of the upper limit for {{math|0 < ''x'' < {{sfrac|1|''c''}}}} and reaches a maximum 
 
: <math> \frac{\omega}{2} = \int_0^\frac{1}{c} \frac{dt}{\sqrt{\left(1 - c^2 t^2\right)\left(1 + e^2 t^2\right)}} </math>

Abel's stroke of genius was now to consider the inverse function {{math|''x'' {{=}} ''φ''(''u'')}} which now is well-defined in the interval {{math|0 ≤ ''u'' ≤ {{sfrac|''ω''|2}}}}. Since the defining integral is an odd function of {{mvar|x}}, the function {{math|''φ''(''u'')}} is also odd with the special values {{math|''φ''(0) {{=}} 0}} and {{math|''φ''(±{{sfrac|''ω''|2}}) {{=}} ±{{sfrac|1|''c''}}}}. The derivative of the function {{math|''φ''′(''u'') {{=}} {{sfrac|''dφ''|''du''}}}} follows also from the integral as

: <math> \frac{d\varphi}{du} = \sqrt{\left(1 - c^2\varphi^2\right)\left(1 + e^2\varphi^2\right)} </math>

and is an even function. The two square roots can be considered to be new, even functions of the argument {{mvar|u}}. Abel defined them as

: <math>\begin{align} f(u) &= \sqrt{1 - c^2\varphi^2(u)} \\ F(u) &= \sqrt{1 + e^2\varphi^2(u)} \end{align}</math>

In this way the derivative can be written on the more compact form {{math|''φ''′(''u'') {{=}} ''f''(''u'')''F''(''u'')}}. These new functions have the derivatives {{math|''f''′(''u'') {{=}} −''c''<sup>2</sup>''φ''(''u'')''F''(''u'')}} and {{math|''F''′(''u'') {{=}} ''e''<sup>2</sup>''φ''(''u'')''f''(''u'')}}. 
  All three elliptic functions depend on the parameters {{mvar|c}} and {{mvar|e}} although this dependence is usually not explicitly written out.

As for the [[trigonometric functions]] Abel could show that these new functions satisfied [[addition theorem]]s in agreement with what [[Euler]] had previously found from such integrals.<ref name = Gray/> They enable the functions to be continued into the whole interval {{math|−''ω'' ≤ ''u'' ≤ ''ω''}} and show that they are periodic with period {{math|2''ω''}}. Furthermore, by letting {{math|''t'' → ''it''}} in the integral the functions can also be defined for complex values of the argument. By this extension the parameters {{mvar|c}} and {{mvar|e}} are exchanged and implies that the functions also have the imaginary period {{math|2''iω''′}} with

: <math>  \frac{\omega'}{2} = \int_0^\frac{1}{e} \frac{dt}{\sqrt{\left(1 - e^2 t^2\right)\left(1 + c^2 t^2\right)}} .</math>

The elliptic functions thus have a double periodicity. Equivalently one can say that they have two complex periods {{math|''ω''<sub>1,2</sub> {{=}} ''ω'' ± ''iω''′}}. Their zeros and poles will thus form a regular, two-dimensional  lattice. Corresponding properties of the [[lemniscatic elliptic function]]s had also been established by Gauss, but not published before after his death.<ref name = Stillwell> J. Stillwell, ''Mathematics and Its History'', Springer, New York (2010). {{isbn|978-1441960528}}.</ref>

==Properties==

*The set of all elliptic functions which share the same two periods form a [[field (mathematics)|field]].
*The [[derivative]] of an elliptic function is again an elliptic function, with the same periods.
*The field of elliptic functions with respect to a given lattice is generated by {{math|℘}} and its derivative {{math|℘′}}.

pages.title: Abel elliptic functions
pages.text:
[[File: Weierstrass elliptic function P.png|thumb|240px|Graphical illustration of an elliptic function where its values are indicated by colours. These are periodically repeated in the two directions of the [[complex plane]].]]
'''Abel elliptic functions''' are [[holomorphic function]]s of one [[complex number|complex variable]] and with [[doubly periodic function|two periods]]. They were first established by [[Niels Henrik Abel]] and are a generalization of [[trigonometric functions]]. Since they are based on [[elliptic integral]]s, they were the first examples of [[elliptic functions]]. Similar functions were shortly thereafter defined by [[Carl Gustav Jacob Jacobi|Carl Gustav Jacobi]]. In spite of the Abel functions having several theoretical advantages, the [[Jacobi elliptic functions]] have become the standard. This can have to do with the fact that Abel died only two years after he presented them while Jacobi could continue with his exploration of them throughout his lifetime.  Both the elliptic functions of Abel and of Jacobi can be derived from a more general formulation which was later given by [[Karl Weierstrass]] based on their double periodicity.

==History==

The first elliptic functions were found by [[Carl Friedrich Gauss]] around 1795 in connection with his calculation of the [[lemniscate]] [[arc length]], but first published after his death.<ref name = Stillwell>J. Stillwell, ''Mathematics and Its History'', Springer, New York (2010). {{ISBN|978-1441960528}}.</ref> These are special cases of the general, [[elliptic function]]s  which were first investigated by [[Niels Henrik Abel|Abel]] in 1823 when he still was a student.<ref name = Stubhaug>A. Stubhaug, ''Niels Henrik Abel and his Times'', Springer-Verlag, Berlin  (2000). {{ISBN|3-540-66834-9}}.</ref> His starting point were the [[elliptic integral]]s which had been studied in great detail by [[Adrien-Marie Legendre]]. The year after Abel could report that his new functions had two [[period (physics)|periods]].<ref name = Ore>O. Ore, ''Niels Henrik Abel – Mathematician Extraordinary'', AMS Chelsea Publishing, Providence, RI (2008). {{ISBN|978-0821846445}}.</ref> Especially this property made them more interesting than the normal [[trigonometric functions]] which have only one period. In particular it meant that they had to be [[complex function]]s which at that time were still in their infancy.

In the following years Abel continued to explore these functions. He also tried to generalize them to functions with even more periods, but seemed to be in no hurry to publish his results. But in the beginning of the year 1827 he wrote together his first, long presentation ''Recherches sur les fonctions elliptiques'' of his discoveries.<ref>N.H. Abel, ''Recherches sur les fonctions elliptiques'', Journal für die reine und angewandte Mathematik, '''2''', 101–181 (1827).</ref> At the end of the same year he became aware of  [[Carl Gustav Jacob Jacobi|Carl Gustav Jacobi]] and his works on new transformations of elliptic integrals. Abel finishes then a second part of his article on elliptic functions and shows in an appendix how the transformation results of Jacobi would easily follow.<ref>N.H. Abel, ''Recherches sur les fonctions elliptiques'', Journal für die reine und angewandte Mathematik, '''3''', 160–190 (1828).</ref> When he then sees the next publication by Jacobi where he makes use of elliptic functions to prove his results without referring to Abel, the Norwegian mathematician finds himself to be in a struggle with Jacobi over priority. He finishes several new articles about related issues, now for the first time dating them, but dies less than a year later. In the meantime Jacobi completes his great work  ''[[Fundamenta nova theoriae functionum ellipticarum]]'' on elliptic functions which appears the same year as a book. It ended up defining what would be the standard form of elliptic functions in the years that followed.

==Properties==

Under his short stay in [[Copenhagen]] in 1823 under the influence of [[Carl Ferdinand Degen]] Abel started to work on the [[elliptic integral]]s which previously had been investigated and classified by [[Adrien-Marie Legendre|Legendre]]. The integral of the first kind he wrote on the symmetric form

: <math> u =  \int_0^x \frac{dt}{\sqrt{(1 - c^2 t^2)(1 + e^2 t^2)}} </math>

where ''c'' and ''e''  are arbitrary parameters. Initially they will be considered to be real numbers, but can eventually also take complex values.<ref name = Gray>J. Gray, ''The Real and the Complex: A History of Analysis in the 19th Century'', Springer, Heidelberg (2015). {{ISBN|978-3-319-23714-5}}.</ref> In the special case {{nowrap|''c'' {{=}} 1}} and {{nowrap|''e'' {{=}} 0}} the integral gives the  [[arc length]] of a [[circle]], while for {{nowrap|''c {{=}} e'' {{=}} 1}} it leads to the arc length of the [[lemniscate]]. He could thus make contact both with the [[trigonometric functions]] (circular functions) and the [[lemniscatic elliptic function|lemniscatic functions]] which [[Gauss]] had hinted at in his ''[[Disquisitiones Arithmeticae]]''.

The value ''u'' of the integral is a function of the upper limit ''x'' of the integral. As long as ''x'' < 1/''c'' this value will increase with increasing ''x'' and reach a maximum

: <math> {\omega\over 2} = \int_0^{1/c} \frac{dt}{\sqrt{(1 - c^2 t^2)(1 + e^2 t^2)}}. </math>

when ''x'' = 1/''c''. So far there was nothing new in this what Legendre had not already done. But Abel's stroke of genius was now to consider the ''inverse function'' ''x'' = ''φ''(''u''). This is well-defined in the interval 0 ≤ ''u'' ≤ ''ω''/2 with {{nowrap|''φ''(0) {{=}} 0}}. Since the defining integral is an odd function of the upper limit, this new function ''φ''(''u'') will also be odd and thus defined in the whole interval {{nowrap|-''ω''/2 ≤ ''u'' ≤ ''ω''/2}} with the special values {{nowrap|''φ''(±''ω''/2) {{=}} ±1/''c''.}}

By taking the derivative with respect to ''u'' on both sides of the integral, the derivative {{nowrap|''dx/du'' {{=}} ''φ' ''(''u'')}} can be found. It leads to

: <math> \varphi'(u) = \sqrt{(1 - c^2\varphi^2(u))(1 + e^2\varphi^2(u))} </math>

which now is an even function {{nowrap|''φ' ''(''u'') {{=}} ''φ' ''(−''u'')}} with the values {{nowrap|''φ' ''(±''ω''/2) {{=}} 0 }} and {{nowrap|''φ' ''(0) {{=}} 1.}}

For the two square roots which here appear Abel introduced the new functions

: <math> f(u) = \sqrt{1 - c^2\varphi^2(u)}, \;\;\; F(u) = \sqrt{1 + e^2\varphi^2(u)} </math>

which also are even. From above one finds ''f''(0) = ''F''(0) = 1 together with {{nowrap|''f''(±''ω''/2) {{=}} 0 }} and {{nowrap|''F''(±''ω''/2) {{=}} {{radic|1 + ''e''<sup>2</sup>/''c''<sup>2</sup>}}}}. If one considers ''φ''(''u'') to be a generalized [[sine|sine function]], then these two even functions can be seen as generalized [[trigonometric functions|cosine functions]] of which there now are two. In terms of them one then has the derivative on the more compact form {{nowrap|''φ' ''(''u'') {{=}} ''f''(''u'')''F''(''u'').}} Similarly, it then follows that  {{nowrap|''f' ''(''u'') {{=}} − ''c''<sup>2</sup>''φ''(''u'')''F''(''u'') }} and {{nowrap|''F' ''(''u'') {{=}} ''e''<sup>2</sup>''φ''(''u'')''f''(''u'').}}

===Addition formulas===

[[Euler]] and [[Adrien-Marie Legendre|Legendre]] had shown that the elliptic integrals satisfied different [[addition theorem]]s. Abel gave a new derivation of this for the particular integral he considered and found

: <math> \varphi(u_1 + u_2) = {\varphi(u_1)f(u_2)F(u_2) + \varphi(u_2)f(u_1)F(u_1)\over 1 + c^2 e^2 \varphi^2(u_1)\varphi^2(u_2)}  </math>

For the two other elliptic functions he similarly obtained

: <math>
\begin{align}
f(u_1 + u_2) & = {f(u_1)f(u_2) - c^2\varphi(u_1)\varphi(u_2)F(u_1)F(u_2)\over 1 + c^2 e^2 \varphi^2(u_1)\varphi^2(u_2)} \\[5pt]
F(u_1 + u_2) & = {F(u_1)F(u_2) + e^2\varphi(u_1)\varphi(u_2)f(u_1)f(u_2)\over 1 + c^2 e^2 \varphi^2(u_1)\varphi^2(u_2)}
\end{align}
</math>

Making use of these he could now extend the range of the argument over which the functions were defined. For example, setting {{nowrap|''u''<sub>1</sub> {{=}} ±''ω''/2}} in the first formula, it gives

: <math> \varphi\big(u \pm {\omega\over 2}\big) =  \pm {1\over c}{f(u)\over F(u)} </math>

and similarly for the two other functions,

: <math> f\big(u \pm {\omega\over 2}\big) = \mp \sqrt{c^2 + e^2}{\varphi(u)\over F(u)}, \;\;  F\big(u \pm {\omega\over 2}\big) = {\sqrt{c^2 + e^2}\over c} {1\over F(u)} </math>

With ''u'' = ''ω''/2 one thus has {{nowrap|''φ''(''ω'') {{=}} 0}} so that the functions will be defined in the whole interval {{nowrap|−''ω'' ≤ ''u'' ≤ ''ω''}}. Repeating this extension one step more, one finds {{nowrap|''φ''(''u + ω'') {{=}} −''φ''(''u'')}}. This function is then periodic ''φ''(''u'' + 2''ω'') = ''φ''(''u'') with period 2''ω''. For the two even functions one similarly obtains {{nowrap|''f''(''u + ω'') {{=}} −''f''(''u'')}} and {{nowrap|''F''(''u + ω'') {{=}} ''F''(''u'')}}. The function ''f''(''u'')  thus also has the period 2''ω'', while  ''F''(''u'') has the shorter period ''ω''.

===Complex extension===

Abel could also extend his new functions into the [[complex plane]]. For that purpose he defined the conjugate integral

: <math> v = \int_0^y \frac{dt}{\sqrt{(1 + c^2 t^2)(1 - e^2 t^2)}} </math>

where the parameters ''c'' are ''e'' are exchanged. The upper limit ''y'' can again be taken as a function of the integral value ''v''. This is a real number and increases steadily from zero to a maximal value

: <math>  {\omega'\over 2} = \int_0^{1/e} \frac{dt}{\sqrt{(1 + c^2 t^2)(1 - e^2 t^2)}} </math>

for ''y'' = 1/''e''.  By changing the integration vaiable from ''t'' to ''it'',  Abel found that {{nowrap|''iy'' {{=}} ''φ''(''iv'')}}. This elliptic function could thus be found for purely imaginary values of the argument. In particular one has {{nowrap|''φ''(''iω'''/2) {{=}} ''i/e''}}. Using the addition theorems one can then calculate the functions for a general complex argument of the form {{nowrap|''w {{=}} u + iv''}}.

For this complex extension one needs also the values of the two other elliptic functions for imaginary arguments. One finds ''f''(±''iω' ''/2) = {{nowrap|{{radic|1 + ''c''<sup>2</sup>/''e''<sup>2</sup>}}}} and {{nowrap|''F''(±''iω'''/2) {{=}} 0}}. Thus it follows that

: <math> \varphi\big(u \pm i{\omega'\over 2}\big) = \pm {i\over e}{F(u)\over f(u)} </math>

and similarly for the two other functions,

: <math> F\big(u \pm i{\omega'\over 2}\big) =  \pm i\sqrt{c^2 + e^2} {\varphi(u)\over f(u)}, \;\;  f\big(u \pm i{\omega'\over 2}\big) = {\sqrt{c^2 + e^2}\over e} {1\over f(u)} </math>

Since ''f''(±''ω''/2) = 0, it follows that the three elliptic functions diverge at ''ω''/2 ± ''iω' ''/2 and other points related by symmetry. These divergences turn out to be  [[pole (complex analysis)|simple poles]], but this part of [[complex analysis]] was not yet so developed at the time of Abel.<ref name = Gray/>

===Double periodicity===

The above complex extension was defined for imaginary arguments in the interval  {{nowrap|−''ω' ''/2 ≤ ''v'' ≤ ''ω' ''/2}}. But using the addition formulas this can be extended to {{nowrap|−''ω' '' ≤ ''v'' ≤ ''ω' ''}}. Replacing then ''u'' with {{nowrap|''u + iω' ''/2}} in the same formulas, it follows that {{nowrap|''φ''(''u + iω' '') {{=}} −''φ''(''u'')}}. This elliptic function is therefore periodic also in the imaginary direction with period  2''iω'''. In addition, one then also has

: <math> \varphi(u + \omega \pm i\omega') = \varphi(u) </math>

so that the function can equivalently be said to have the two complex periods {{nowrap|''ω''<sub>1,2</sub> {{=}} ''ω'' ± ''i'' ''ω' ''}}. Since ''φ''(0) = 0, the function will also be zero in all points {{nowrap|''w'' {{=}} ''mω + inω' ''}} where ''m'' and ''n'' are integers.  These zeros thus form a regular lattice in the [[complex plane]] as the poles also will.

For the two other functions Abel found {{nowrap|''f''(''u + iω' '') {{=}} ''f''(''u'')}} and {{nowrap|''F''(''u + iω' '') {{=}} −''F''(''u'')}}. The function ''f''(''u'')  thus has the period ''iω' '' in the imaginary direction while it is  2''iω' '' for ''F''(''u''). Their zeros and poles will again form a regular lattice reflecting their double periodicity. After Gauss had died it was discovered that he had discovered a corresponding double periodicity in his [[lemniscate elliptic function]].<ref name = Stillwell/>

===Jacobi elliptic functions===

From the defining integrals one sees that Abel's elliptic functions can be expressed by the [[Jacobi elliptic functions]] for imaginary values ''k'' = ''ie''/''c'' of the modulus. The precise relation between these functions can be found by a change of the integration variable and is

: <math> \varphi(u;c,e) = {1\over c} \operatorname{sn}(cu,ie/c) </math>

For the two secondary functions this results in

: <math> f(u;c,e) = \operatorname{cn}(cu,ie/c), \;\; F(u;c,e) = \operatorname{dn}(cu,ie/c) </math>

After Abel died in 1829 Jacobi continued his investigations of the elliptic functions. With time they became numerically tabulated and ended up being the standard elliptic functions.<ref name = Abramowitz-Stegun>M. Abramowitz and I.A. Stegun, ''Handbook of Mathematical Functions'', Dover Publications, New York (1983).  {{ISBN|0-486-61272-4}}.</ref>  Using these for imaginary values of the modulus, one can therefore also calculate the corresponding Abel elliptic functions.

==References==

''Collected Works'', Oslo (1881).
* Christian Houzel, [http://www.abelprisen.no/c53052/binfil/download.php?tid=53200 ''The Work of Niels Henrik Abel''], in O.A. Laudal and R. Piene, ''The Legacy of Niels Henrik Abel – The Abel Bicentennial, Oslo 2002'', Springer Verlag, Berlin (2004). {{ISBN|3-540-43826-2}}.

pages.title: Carlson symmetric form
pages.text:
In [[mathematics]], the '''Carlson symmetric forms of [[elliptic integral]]s''' are a small canonical set of elliptic integrals to which all others may be reduced. They are a modern alternative to the [[Legendre form]]s. The Legendre forms may be expressed in terms of the Carlson forms and vice versa.

The Carlson elliptic integrals are:

:<math>R_F(x,y,z) = \tfrac{1}{2}\int_0^\infty \frac{dt}{\sqrt{(t+x)(t+y)(t+z)}}</math>

:<math>R_J(x,y,z,p) = \tfrac{3}{2}\int_0^\infty \frac{dt}{(t+p)\sqrt{(t+x)(t+y)(t+z)}}</math>

:<math>R_C(x,y) = R_F(x,y,y) = \tfrac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty \frac{dt}{(t+y)\sqrt{(t+x)}}</math>

:<math>R_D(x,y,z) = R_J(x,y,z,z) = \tfrac{3}{2} \int_0^\infty \frac{dt}{ (t+z) \,\sqrt{(t+x)(t+y)(t+z)}}</math>

Since <math>\scriptstyle{R_C}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{R_D}</math> are special cases of <math>\scriptstyle{R_F}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{R_J}</math>, all elliptic integrals can ultimately be evaluated in terms of just <math>\scriptstyle{R_F}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{R_J}</math>.

The term ''symmetric'' refers to the fact that in contrast to the Legendre forms, these functions are unchanged by the exchange of certain of their arguments. The value of <math>\scriptstyle{R_F(x,y,z)}</math> is the same for any permutation of its arguments, and the value of <math>\scriptstyle{R_J(x,y,z,p)}</math> is the same for any permutation of its first three arguments.

The Carlson elliptic integrals are named after Bille C. Carlson.

==Relation to the Legendre forms==

===Incomplete elliptic integrals===

Incomplete [[elliptic integral]]s can be calculated easily using Carlson symmetric forms:

:<math>F(\phi,k)=\sin\phi R_F\left(\cos^2\phi,1-k^2\sin^2\phi,1\right) </math>

:<math>E(\phi,k)=\sin\phi R_F\left(\cos^2\phi,1-k^2\sin^2\phi,1\right) -\tfrac{1}{3}k^2\sin^3\phi R_D\left(\cos^2\phi,1-k^2\sin^2\phi,1\right)</math>

:<math>\Pi(\phi,n,k)=\sin\phi R_F\left(\cos^2\phi,1-k^2\sin^2\phi,1\right)+
\tfrac{1}{3}n\sin^3\phi R_J\left(\cos^2\phi,1-k^2\sin^2\phi,1,1-n\sin^2\phi\right)</math>

(Note: the above are only valid for <math>0\le\phi\le2\pi</math> and <math>0\le k^2\sin^2\phi\le1</math>)

===Complete elliptic integrals===

Complete [[elliptic integral]]s can be calculated by substituting φ = {{frac|1|2}}π:

:<math>K(k)=R_F\left(0,1-k^2,1\right) </math>

:<math>E(k)=R_F\left(0,1-k^2,1\right)-\tfrac{1}{3}k^2 R_D\left(0,1-k^2,1\right)</math>

:<math>\Pi(n,k)=R_F\left(0,1-k^2,1\right)+\tfrac{1}{3}n R_J \left(0,1-k^2,1,1-n\right) </math>

==Special cases==

When any two, or all three of the arguments of <math>R_F</math> are the same, then a substitution of <math>\sqrt{t + x} = u</math> renders the integrand rational. The integral can then be expressed in terms of elementary transcendental functions.

:<math>R_{C}(x,y) = R_{F}(x,y,y) = \frac{1}{2} \int _{0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{\sqrt{t + x} (t + y)} dt =
\int _{\sqrt{x}}^{\infty}\frac{1}{u^{2} - x + y} du =
\begin{cases}
  \frac{\arccos \sqrt{\frac{x}{y}}}{\sqrt{y - x}},  & x < y \\
  \frac{1}{\sqrt{y}}, & x = y \\
  \frac{\mathrm{arccosh} \sqrt{\frac{x}{y}}}{\sqrt{x - y}},  & x > y \\
\end{cases}</math>

Similarly, when at least two of the first three arguments of <math>R_J</math> are the same,

:<math>R_{J}(x,y,y,p) = 3 \int _{\sqrt{x}}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(u^{2} - x + y) (u^{2} - x + p)} du =
\begin{cases}
  \frac{3}{p - y} (R_{C}(x,y) - R_{C}(x,p)),  & y \ne p \\
  \frac{3}{2 (y - x)} \left( R_{C}(x,y) - \frac{1}{y} \sqrt{x}\right),  & y = p \ne x \\
  \frac{1}{y^{\frac{3}{2}}},  &y = p = x \\
\end{cases}</math>

==Properties==

===Homogeneity===

By substituting in the integral definitions <math>t = \kappa u</math> for any constant <math>\kappa</math>, it is found that

:<math>R_F\left(\kappa x,\kappa y,\kappa z\right)=\kappa^{-1/2}R_F(x,y,z)</math>

:<math>R_J\left(\kappa x,\kappa y,\kappa z,\kappa p\right)=\kappa^{-3/2}R_J(x,y,z,p)</math>

===Duplication theorem===

:<math>R_F(x,y,z)=2R_F(x+\lambda,y+\lambda,z+\lambda)=
R_F\left(\frac{x+\lambda}{4},\frac{y+\lambda}{4},\frac{z+\lambda}{4}\right),</math>

where <math>\lambda=\sqrt{x}\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{y}\sqrt{z}+\sqrt{z}\sqrt{x}</math>.

:<math>\begin{align}R_{J}(x,y,z,p) & = 2 R_{J}(x + \lambda,y + \lambda,z + \lambda,p + \lambda) + 6 R_{C}(d^{2},d^{2} + (p - x) (p - y) (p - z)) \\
 & = \frac{1}{4} R_{J}\left( \frac{x + \lambda}{4},\frac{y + \lambda}{4},\frac{z + \lambda}{4},\frac{p + \lambda}{4}\right) + 6 R_{C}(d^{2},d^{2} + (p - x) (p - y) (p - z)) \end{align}</math><ref name="Carlson94"/>

where <math>d = (\sqrt{p} + \sqrt{x}) (\sqrt{p} + \sqrt{y}) (\sqrt{p} + \sqrt{z})</math> and <math>\lambda =\sqrt{x}\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{y}\sqrt{z}+\sqrt{z}\sqrt{x}</math>

==Series Expansion==

In obtaining a [[Taylor series]] expansion for <math>\scriptstyle{R_{F}}</math> or <math>\scriptstyle{R_{J}}</math> it proves convenient to expand about the mean value of the several arguments. So for <math>\scriptstyle{R_{F}}</math>, letting the mean value of the arguments be <math>\scriptstyle{A = (x + y + z)/3}</math>, and using homogeneity, define <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta x}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta y}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta z}</math> by

:<math>\begin{align}R_{F}(x,y,z) & = R_{F}(A (1 - \Delta x),A (1 - \Delta y),A (1 - \Delta z)) \\
 & = \frac{1}{\sqrt{A}} R_{F}(1 - \Delta x,1 - \Delta y,1 - \Delta z) \end{align}</math>

that is <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta x = 1 - x/A}</math> etc. The differences <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta x}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta y}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta z}</math> are defined with this sign (such that they are ''subtracted''), in order to be in agreement with Carlson's papers. Since <math>\scriptstyle{R_{F}(x,y,z)}</math> is symmetric under permutation of <math>\scriptstyle{x}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{y}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{z}</math>, it is also symmetric in the quantities <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta x}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta y}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta z}</math>. It follows that both the integrand of <math>\scriptstyle{R_{F}}</math> and its integral can be expressed as functions of the [[elementary symmetric polynomial]]s in <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta x}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta y}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta z}</math> which are

:<math>E_{1} = \Delta x + \Delta y + \Delta z = 0</math>

:<math>E_{2} = \Delta x \Delta y + \Delta y \Delta z + \Delta z \Delta x</math>

:<math>E_{3} = \Delta x \Delta y \Delta z</math>

Expressing the integrand in terms of these polynomials, performing a multidimensional Taylor expansion and integrating term-by-term...

:<math>\begin{align}R_{F}(x,y,z) & = \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{A}} \int _{0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{\sqrt{(t + 1)^{3} - (t + 1)^{2} E_{1} + (t + 1) E_{2} - E_{3}}} dt \\
 & = \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{A}} \int _{0}^{\infty}\left( \frac{1}{(t + 1)^{\frac{3}{2}}} - \frac{E_{2}}{2 (t + 1)^{\frac{7}{2}}} + \frac{E_{3}}{2 (t + 1)^{\frac{9}{2}}} + \frac{3 E_{2}^{2}}{8 (t + 1)^{\frac{11}{2}}} - \frac{3 E_{2} E_{3}}{4 (t + 1)^{\frac{13}{2}}} + O(E_{1}) + O(\Delta^{6})\right) dt \\
 & = \frac{1}{\sqrt{A}} \left( 1 - \frac{1}{10} E_{2} + \frac{1}{14} E_{3} + \frac{1}{24} E_{2}^{2} - \frac{3}{44} E_{2} E_{3} + O(E_{1}) + O(\Delta^{6})\right) \end{align}</math>

The advantage of expanding about the mean value of the arguments is now apparent; it reduces <math>\scriptstyle{E_{1}}</math> identically to zero, and so eliminates all terms involving <math>\scriptstyle{E_{1}}</math> - which otherwise would be the most numerous.

An ascending series for <math>\scriptstyle{R_{J}}</math> may be found in a similar way. There is a slight difficulty because <math>\scriptstyle{R_{J}}</math> is not fully symmetric; its dependence on its fourth argument, <math>\scriptstyle{p}</math>, is different from its dependence on <math>\scriptstyle{x}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{y}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{z}</math>. This is overcome by treating <math>\scriptstyle{R_{J}}</math> as a fully symmetric function of ''five'' arguments, two of which happen to have the same value <math>\scriptstyle{p}</math>. The mean value of the arguments is therefore taken to be

:<math>A = \frac{x + y + z + 2 p}{5}</math>

and the differences <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta x}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta y}</math> <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta z}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta p}</math> defined by

:<math>\begin{align}R_{J}(x,y,z,p) & = R_{J}(A (1 - \Delta x),A (1 - \Delta y),A (1 - \Delta z),A (1 - \Delta p)) \\
 & = \frac{1}{A^{\frac{3}{2}}} R_{J}(1 - \Delta x,1 - \Delta y,1 - \Delta z,1 - \Delta p) \end{align}</math>

The [[elementary symmetric polynomial]]s in <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta x}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta y}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta z}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta p}</math> and (again) <math>\scriptstyle{\Delta p}</math> are in full

:<math>E_{1} = \Delta x + \Delta y + \Delta z + 2 \Delta p = 0</math>

:<math>E_{2} = \Delta x \Delta y + \Delta y \Delta z + 2 \Delta z \Delta p + \Delta p^{2} + 2 \Delta p \Delta x + \Delta x \Delta z + 2 \Delta y \Delta p</math>

:<math>E_{3} = \Delta z \Delta p^{2} + \Delta x \Delta p^{2} + 2 \Delta x \Delta y \Delta p + \Delta x \Delta y \Delta z + 2 \Delta y \Delta z \Delta p + \Delta y \Delta p^{2} + 2 \Delta x \Delta z \Delta p</math>

:<math>E_{4} = \Delta y \Delta z \Delta p^{2} + \Delta x \Delta z \Delta p^{2} + \Delta x \Delta y \Delta p^{2} + 2 \Delta x \Delta y \Delta z \Delta p</math>

:<math>E_{5} = \Delta x \Delta y \Delta z \Delta p^{2}</math>

However, it is possible to simplify the formulae for <math>\scriptstyle{E_{2}}</math>, <math>\scriptstyle{E_{3}}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle{E_{4}}</math> using the fact that <math>\scriptstyle{E_{1} = 0}</math>. Expressing the integrand in terms of these polynomials, performing a multidimensional Taylor expansion and integrating term-by-term as before...

:<math>\begin{align}R_{J}(x,y,z,p) & = \frac{3}{2 A^{\frac{3}{2}}} \int _{0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{\sqrt{(t + 1)^{5} - (t + 1)^{4} E_{1} + (t + 1)^{3} E_{2} - (t + 1)^{2} E_{3} + (t + 1) E_{4} - E_{5}}} dt \\
 & = \frac{3}{2 A^{\frac{3}{2}}} \int _{0}^{\infty}\left( \frac{1}{(t + 1)^{\frac{5}{2}}} - \frac{E_{2}}{2 (t + 1)^{\frac{9}{2}}} + \frac{E_{3}}{2 (t + 1)^{\frac{11}{2}}} + \frac{3 E_{2}^{2} - 4 E_{4}}{8 (t + 1)^{\frac{13}{2}}} + \frac{2 E_{5} - 3 E_{2} E_{3}}{4 (t + 1)^{\frac{15}{2}}} + O(E_{1}) + O(\Delta^{6})\right) dt \\
 & = \frac{1}{A^{\frac{3}{2}}} \left( 1 - \frac{3}{14} E_{2} + \frac{1}{6} E_{3} + \frac{9}{88} E_{2}^{2} - \frac{3}{22} E_{4} - \frac{9}{52} E_{2} E_{3} + \frac{3}{26} E_{5} + O(E_{1}) + O(\Delta^{6})\right) \end{align}</math>

As with <math>\scriptstyle{R_{J}}</math>, by expanding about the mean value of the arguments, more than half the terms (those involving <math>\scriptstyle{E_{1}}</math>) are eliminated.

==Negative arguments==

In general, the arguments x, y, z of Carlson's integrals may not be real and negative, as this would place a [[branch point]] on the path of integration, making the integral ambiguous. However, if the second argument of <math>\scriptstyle{R_C}</math>, or the fourth argument, p, of <math>\scriptstyle{R_J}</math> is negative, then this results in a [[simple pole]] on the path of integration. In these cases the [[Cauchy principal value]] (finite part) of the integrals may be of interest; these are

:<math>\mathrm{p.v.}\; R_C(x, -y) = \sqrt{\frac{x}{x + y}}\,R_C(x + y, y),</math>

and

:<math>\begin{align}\mathrm{p.v.}\; R_{J}(x,y,z,-p) & = \frac{(q - y) R_{J}(x,y,z,q) - 3 R_{F}(x,y,z) + 3 \sqrt{y} R_{C}(x z,- p q)}{y + p} \\
 & = \frac{(q - y) R_{J}(x,y,z,q) - 3 R_{F}(x,y,z) + 3 \sqrt{\frac{x y z}{x z + p q}} R_{C}(x z + p q,p q)}{y + p} \end{align}</math>
where

:<math>q = y + \frac{(z - y) (y - x)}{y + p}.</math>

which must be greater than zero for <math>\scriptstyle{R_{J}(x,y,z,q)}</math> to be evaluated. This may be arranged by permuting x, y and z so that the value of y is between that of x and z.

==Numerical evaluation==

The duplication theorem can be used for a fast and robust evaluation of the Carlson symmetric form of elliptic integrals
and therefore also for the evaluation of Legendre-form of elliptic integrals. Let us calculate <math>R_F(x,y,z)</math>:
first, define <math>x_0=x</math>, <math>y_0=y</math> and <math>z_0=z</math>. Then iterate the series

:<math>\lambda_n=\sqrt{x_n}\sqrt{y_n}+\sqrt{y_n}\sqrt{z_n}+\sqrt{z_n}\sqrt{x_n},</math>
:<math>x_{n+1}=\frac{x_n+\lambda_n}{4}, y_{n+1}=\frac{y_n+\lambda_n}{4}, z_{n+1}=\frac{z_n+\lambda_n}{4}</math>
until the desired precision is reached: if <math>x</math>, <math>y</math> and <math>z</math> are non-negative, all of the series will converge quickly to a given value, say, <math>\mu</math>. Therefore,

:<math>R_F\left(x,y,z\right)=R_F\left(\mu,\mu,\mu\right)=\mu^{-1/2}.</math>

Evaluating <math>R_C(x,y)</math> is much the same due to the relation

:<math>R_C\left(x,y\right)=R_F\left(x,y,y\right).</math>

pages.title: Dedekind eta function
pages.text:
{{distinguish|Weierstrass eta function|Dirichlet eta function}}
[[Image:Dedekind Eta.jpg|right|thumb|500px|Dedekind η-function in the upper half-plane]]
In [[mathematics]], the '''Dedekind eta function''', named after [[Richard Dedekind]], is a [[modular form]] of weight 1/2 and is a function defined on the [[upper half-plane]] of [[complex number]]s, where the imaginary part is positive.

==Definition==
For any complex number <math>\tau </math> with <math>\mathrm{Im}(\tau) > 0</math>, let <math> q= e^{2\pi i \tau}</math>, then the eta function is defined by,

:<math>\eta(\tau) = e^{\frac{\pi \rm{i} \tau}{12}} \prod_{n=1}^{\infty} (1-e^{2 n\pi \rm{i} \tau})=q^{\frac{1}{24}} \prod_{n=1}^{\infty} (1-q^{n}) .</math>

The notation <math>q \equiv e^{2\pi \rm{i} \tau}\,</math> is now standard in [[number theory]], though many older books use ''q'' for  the [[nome (mathematics)|nome]] <math>e^{\pi \rm{i} \tau}\,</math>. Raising the eta equation to the 24th power and multiplying by (2π)<sup>12</sup> gives

:<math>\Delta(\tau)=(2\pi)^{12}\eta^{24}(\tau)</math>

where Δ is the [[modular discriminant]].  The presence of [[24 (number)|24]] can be understood by connection with other occurrences, such as in the 24-dimensional [[Leech lattice]].

The eta function is [[Holomorphic function|holomorphic]] on the upper half-plane but cannot be continued analytically beyond it.

[[File:Q-Eulero.jpeg|thumb|right|Modulus of Euler phi on the unit disc, colored so that black=0, red=4]]
[[Image:Discriminant real part.jpeg|thumb|right|The real part of the modular discriminant as a function of ''q''.]]

The eta function satisfies the [[functional equation]]s<ref>{{cite journal|author=Siegel, C.L.|title=A Simple Proof of <math>\eta(-1/\tau) = \eta(\tau)\sqrt{\tau/{\rm{i}}}\,</math>|journal=Mathematika|year=1954|volume=1|page=4|doi=10.1112/S0025579300000462}}</ref>

:<math>\eta(\tau+1) =e^{\frac{\pi {\rm{i}}}{12}}\eta(\tau),\,</math>

:<math>\eta(-\tfrac{1}{\tau}) = \sqrt{-{\rm{i}}\tau} \eta(\tau).\,</math>

More generally, suppose ''a'', ''b'', ''c'', ''d'' are integers with ''ad'' − ''bc'' = 1, so that

:<math>\tau\mapsto\frac{a\tau+b}{c\tau+d}</math>

is a transformation belonging to the [[modular group]].  We may assume that either ''c'' > 0, or ''c'' = 0 and ''d'' = 1.  Then

:<math>\eta \left( \frac{a\tau+b}{c\tau+d} \right) = 
\epsilon (a,b,c,d) (c\tau+d)^{\frac{1}{2}} \eta(\tau),</math>

where

:<math>\epsilon (a,b,c,d)=e^{\frac{b{\rm{i}} \pi}{12}}\quad(c=0,d=1);</math>
:<math>\epsilon (a,b,c,d)=e^{{\rm{i}}\pi [\frac{a+d}{12c} - s(d,c)
-\frac{1}{4}]}\quad(c>0).</math>

Here <math>s(h,k)</math> is the [[Dedekind sum]]

:<math>s(h,k)=\sum_{n=1}^{k-1} \frac{n}{k}
\left( \frac{hn}{k} - \left\lfloor \frac{hn}{k} \right\rfloor -\frac{1}{2} \right).</math>

Because of these functional equations the eta function is a [[modular form]] of weight 1/2 and level 1 for a certain character of order 24 of the [[metaplectic group|metaplectic double cover]] of the modular group, and can be used to define other modular forms. In particular the [[modular discriminant]] of [[Weierstrass]] can be defined as

:<math>\Delta(\tau) = (2 \pi)^{12} \eta(\tau)^{24}\,</math>

and is a modular form of weight 12. (Some authors omit the factor of (2π)<sup>12</sup>, so that the series expansion has integral coefficients).

The [[Jacobi triple product]] implies that the eta is (up to a factor) a Jacobi [[theta function]] for special values of the arguments:

:<math>\eta(\tau) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \chi(n) \exp(\tfrac{1}{12} \pi i n^2 \tau),</math>{{Citation needed|date=September 2016}}

where <math>\chi(n)</math> is "the" [[Dirichlet character]] modulo 12 with <math>\chi(\pm1) = 1</math>,
<math>\chi(\pm 5)=-1</math>. Explicitly,

:<math>\eta(\tau) = e^{\tfrac{\pi i \tau}{12}}\vartheta(\tfrac{\tau+1}{2}; 3\tau).</math>{{Citation needed|date=September 2016}}
The [[Euler function]]

:<math>\phi(q) = \prod_{n=1}^{\infty} \left(1-q^n\right),</math>

related to <math>\eta \,</math> by <math>\phi(q)= q^{-1/24} \eta(\tau)\,</math>, has a power series
by the [[Pentagonal number theorem|Euler identity]]:

:<math>\phi(q)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty (-1)^n q^{(3n^2-n)/2}.</math>

Because the eta function is easy to compute numerically from either [[power series]], it is often helpful in computation to express other functions in terms of it when possible, and products and quotients of eta functions, called eta quotients, can be used to express a great variety of modular forms.

The picture on this page shows the modulus of the Euler function: the additional factor of <math>q^{1/24}</math> between this and eta makes almost no visual difference whatsoever (it only introduces a tiny pinprick at the origin).  Thus, this picture can be taken as a picture of eta as a function of ''q''.

== Combinatorial identities==
The theory of the [[algebraic character]]s of the [[affine Lie algebra]]s gives rise to a large class of previously unknown identities for the eta function. These identities follow from the [[Weyl-Kac character formula]], and more specifically from the so-called "denominator identities". The characters themselves allow the construction of generalizations of the [[Jacobi theta function]] which transform under the [[modular group]]; this is what leads to the identities. An example of one such new identity<ref>{{citation|first=Jurgen|last= Fuchs|title=Affine Lie Algebras and Quantum Groups|year=1992|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0-521-48412-X}}</ref> is

:<math>\eta(8\tau)\eta(16\tau) = \sum_{m,n\in \mathbb{Z} \atop m \le |3n|} 
(-1)^m q^{(2m+1)^2 - 32n^2} 
</math>
where <math>q=\exp 2\pi i \tau</math> is the [[q-analog]] or "deformation" of the [[highest weight]] of a module.

==Special values==

The above connection with the Euler function together with the special values of the latter, it can be easily deduced that

: <math>
\eta(i)=\frac{\Gamma \left(\frac{1}{4}\right)}{2 \pi ^{3/4}}
</math>

: <math>
\eta\left(\tfrac{1}{2}i\right)=\frac{\Gamma \left(\frac{1}{4}\right)}{2^{7/8} \pi ^{3/4}}
</math>

: <math>
\eta(2i)=\frac{\Gamma \left(\frac{1}{4}\right)}{2^{{11}/8} \pi ^{3/4}}
</math>

: <math>
\eta(3i)=\frac{\Gamma \left(\frac{1}{4}\right)}{2(3^{1/3}) (3+2 \sqrt{3})^{1/12} \pi ^{3/4}}
</math>

: <math>
\eta(4i)=\frac{\sqrt[4]{-1+\sqrt{2}}\; \Gamma \left(\frac{1}{4}\right)}{2^{{29}/16} \pi ^{3/4}}
</math>

: <math>
\eta(e^{2\pi i/3})=e^{-\frac{\pi i}{24}}\frac{\sqrt[8]{3}  \Gamma \left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{3/2}}{2 \pi }
</math>

==Eta quotients==
Eta quotients are defined by quotients of the form
:<math> \prod_{0<d\mid N}\eta(d\tau)^{r_d} </math>
Where <math>d</math> is a non-negative integer and <math>r_d</math> is any integer. Linear combinations of eta quotients at imaginary quadratic arguments may be [[algebraic number|algebraic]], while combinations of eta quotients may even be [[integer|integral]]. For example, define,

:<math>j(\tau)=\Big(\big(\tfrac{\eta(\tau)}{\eta(2\tau)}\big)^{8}+2^8 \big(\tfrac{\eta(2\tau)}{\eta(\tau)}\big)^{16}\Big)^3</math>

:<math>j_{2A}(\tau)=\Big(\big(\tfrac{\eta(\tau)}{\eta(2\tau)}\big)^{12}+2^6 \big(\tfrac{\eta(2\tau)}{\eta(\tau)}\big)^{12}\Big)^2</math>

:<math>j_{3A}(\tau) =\Big(\big(\tfrac{\eta(\tau)}{\eta(3\tau)}\big)^{6}+3^3 \big(\tfrac{\eta(3\tau)}{\eta(\tau)}\big)^{6}\Big)^2</math>

:<math>j_{4A}(\tau)=\Big(\big(\tfrac{\eta(\tau)}{\eta(4\tau)}\big)^{4}+4^2 \big(\tfrac{\eta(4\tau)}{\eta(\tau)}\big)^{4}\Big)^2 = \Big(\tfrac{\eta^2(2\tau)}{\eta(\tau)\,\eta(4\tau)} \Big)^{24} </math>

with 24th power of the [[Weber modular function]] <math>\mathfrak{f}(\tau)</math>. Then,

:<math>j\Big(\tfrac{1+\sqrt{-163}}{2}\Big) = -640320^3,\quad e^{\pi\sqrt{163}} \approx 640320^3+743.99999999999925\dots</math>

:<math>j_{2A}\Big(\tfrac{\sqrt{-58}}{2}\Big) = 396^4,\qquad \quad e^{\pi\sqrt{58}}\approx 396^4-104.00000017\dots</math>

:<math>j_{3A}\Big(\tfrac{1+\sqrt{-89/3}}{2}\Big) = -300^3,\quad e^{\pi\sqrt{89/3}}\approx 300^3+41.999971\dots</math>

:<math>j_{4A}\Big(\tfrac{\sqrt{-7}}{2}\Big)=2^{12},\qquad \quad \quad e^{\pi\sqrt{7}}\approx 2^{12}-24.06\dots</math>

and so on, values which appear in [[Ramanujan–Sato series]].

Eta Quotients may also be a useful tool for describing bases of [[modular form|modular forms]], which are notoriously difficult to compute and express directly. In 1993 Basil Gordon and Kim Hughes proved that if an eta quotient <math>\eta_g</math> of the form <math> \prod_{0<d\mid N}\eta(d\tau)^{r_d} </math> satisfies
:<math> \sum_{0<d\mid N}d r_d \equiv 0 \pmod{24} \text{ and,}</math>
:<math> \sum_{0<d\mid N}\frac{N}{d}r_d \equiv 0 \pmod{24},</math>
then <math>\eta_g</math> is a [[modular form|weight <math>k</math> modular form]] for the [[congruence subgroup]] <math>\Gamma_0(N)</math> (up to [[Holomorphic function|holomorphicity]]) where 
:<math>k=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{0<d\mid N} r_d.</math><ref>Basil Gordon and Kim Hughes. Multiplicative properties of η-products. II. In A tribute to Emil Grosswald:
number theory and related analysis, volume 143 of Contemp. Math., pages 415–430. Amer. Math. Soc., Providence,
RI, 1993.</ref>
This result was extended in 2019 such that the converse holds for cases when <math>N</math> is [[Coprime integers| coprime]] to <math>6</math>, and it remains open that the original theorem is sharp for all integers <math>N</math>.<ref>Michael Allen et al. “Eta-quotients of Prime or Semiprime Level and Elliptic Curves”. In:
arXiv e-prints, arXiv:1901.10511 (Jan. 2019), arXiv:1901.10511. arXiv: 1901.10511 [math.NT].</ref>  This also extends to state that any [[modular form|modular eta quotient]] for any [[Congruence subgroup| level <math>n</math> congruence subgroup]] must also be a modular form for the group <math>\Gamma(N)</math>. While these theorems characterize [[Modular form|modular]] eta quotients, the condition of [[Holomorphic function| holomorphicity]] must be checked separately using a theorem that emerged from the work of Gérard Ligozat<ref>G. Ligozat. Courbes modulaires de genre 1. U.E.R. Mathématique, Université Paris XI, Orsay, 1974. Publication
Mathématique d’Orsay, No. 75 7411.</ref> and Yves Martin<ref>Yves Martin. Multiplicative η-quotients. Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 348(12):4825–4856, 1996.</ref>:

If <math>\eta_g</math> is an eta quotient satisfying the above conditions for the integer <math>N</math> and <math>c</math> and <math>d</math> are coprime integers, then the order of vanishing at the [[Cusp (singularity)| cusp]] <math>\frac{c}{d}</math> relative to <math>\Gamma_0(N)</math> is 
:<math>\frac{N}{24}\sum_{0<\delta|N} \frac{\gcd(d,\delta)^2r_\delta}{\gcd(d,\frac{N}{\delta})d\delta}</math>.
These theorems provide an effective means of creating holomorphic modular eta quotients, however this may not be sufficient to construct a basis for a [[vector space]] of modular forms and [[cusp form|cusp forms]]. A useful theorem for limiting the number of modular eta quotients to consider states that a holomorphic weight <math>k</math> modular eta quotient on <math>\Gamma_0(N)</math> must satisfy
:<math>\sum_{0<d\mid N} |r_d|\leq \prod_{p\mid N}\left(\frac{p+1}{p-1}\right)^{\min(2,\text{ord}_p(N))},</math>
where <math>\text{ord}_p(N)</math> denotes the largest integer <math>m</math> such that <math>p^m\mid N</math>.<ref>Jeremy Rouse and John J. Webb. On spaces of modular forms spanned by eta-quotients. Adv. Math., 272:200–224,
2015.</ref>
These results lead to several characterizations of spaces of modular forms that can be spanned by modular eta quotients.<ref>Jeremy Rouse and John J. Webb. On spaces of modular forms spanned by eta-quotients. Adv. Math., 272:200–224,
2015.</ref> Using the [[graded ring]] structure on the ring of modular forms, we can compute bases of vector spaces of modular forms composed of <math>\mathbb{C}</math>-linear combinations of eta-quotients. For example, if we assume <math>N=pq</math> is a [[semiprime]] then the following process can be used to compute an eta-quotient basis of [[modular form|<math>M_k(\Gamma_0(N))</math>]].<ref>Michael Allen et al. “Eta-quotients of Prime or Semiprime Level and Elliptic Curves”. In:
arXiv e-prints, arXiv:1901.10511 (Jan. 2019), arXiv:1901.10511. arXiv: 1901.10511 [math.NT].</ref>

Step 1: 
Fix a semiprime <math>N=pq</math> which is coprime to 6. We know that any modular eta quotient may be found using the above theorems, therefore it is reasonable to algorithmically to compute them.

Step 2:
Compute the dimension <math>D</math> of <math>M_k(\Gamma_0(N))</math>. This tells us how many linearly independent modular eta quotients we will need to compute to form a basis.

Step 3:
Reduce the number of eta quotients to consider. For semiprimes we can reduce the number of partitions using the bound on
:<math>\sum_{0<d\mid N} |r_d|</math> 
and by noticing that the sum of the orders of vanishing at the cusps of <math>\Gamma_0(N)</math> must equal
:<math>S:=\frac{(p+1)(q+1)}{6}</math>.<ref>Michael Allen et al. “Eta-quotients of Prime or Semiprime Level and Elliptic Curves”. In:
arXiv e-prints, arXiv:1901.10511 (Jan. 2019), arXiv:1901.10511. arXiv: 1901.10511 [math.NT].</ref>

Step 4:
Find all partitions of <math>S</math> into 4-tuples (there are 4 cusps of <math>\Gamma_0(N)</math>), and among these consider only the partitions which satisfy Gordon and Hughes' conditions (we can convert orders of vanishing into exponents). Each of these partitions corresponds to a unique eta quotient.

Step 5:
Determine the minimum number of terms in the [[modular form|q-expansion]] of each eta quotient required to identify elements uniquely (this uses a result known as Sturm's Bound). Then use linear algebra to determine a maximal independent set among these eta quotients.

Step 6:
Assuming that we have not found <math>D</math> many linearly independent eta quotients. Find an appropriate vector space <math>M_{k'}(\Gamma_0(N))</math> such that <math>k'</math> and <math>M_{k'}(\Gamma_0(N))</math> is spanned by ([[Weakly holomorphic modular form|weakly holomorphic]]) eta quotients,<ref>Jeremy Rouse and John J. Webb. On spaces of modular forms spanned by eta-quotients. Adv. Math., 272:200–224,
2015.</ref> and <math>M_{k'-k}(\Gamma_0(N)</math> contains an eta quotient <math>\eta_g</math>.

Step 7:
Take a weight <math>k</math> modular form <math>f</math> not in the span of our computed eta-quotients and compute <math>f\eta_g</math> as a linear combination of eta-quotients in <math>M_{k'}(\Gamma_0(N))</math> and then divide out by <math>\eta_g</math>. The result will be an expression of <math>f</math> as a linear combination of eta quotients as desired. Repeat this until a basis is formed.

pages.title: Elliptic rational functions
pages.text:
[[File:Rational Elliptic Functions (n=1,2,3,4, x=--1,1-).svg|thumb|right|300px|Plot of elliptic rational functions for x between -1 and 1 for orders 1,2,3 and 4 with discrimination factor ξ=1.1. Note that all are bounded between -1 and 1 and all have the value 1 at ''x=1''.]]

In [[mathematics]] the '''elliptic rational functions''' are a sequence of [[rational functions]] with real coefficients. Elliptic rational functions are extensively used in the design of [[elliptic filter|elliptic electronic filter]]s. (These functions are sometimes called '''Chebyshev rational functions''', not to be confused with certain other functions of the [[Chebyshev rational functions|same name]]).

Rational elliptic functions are identified by a positive integer order ''n'' and include a parameter ξ ≥ 1 called the '''selectivity factor'''. A rational elliptic function of degree ''n'' in ''x'' with selectivity factor ξ is generally defined as:

:<math>R_n(\xi,x)\equiv \mathrm{cd}\left(n\frac{K(1/L_n)}{K(1/\xi)}\,\mathrm{cd}^{-1}(x,1/\xi),1/L_n\right)</math>

I thought, to be a rational function it is  required that a condition Ｋ'(1/L_n) / K(1/L_n) = n K'(1/\xi) / K(1/\xi)  to hold, here K'(k) = K'(\sqrt(1-k^2)).

* cd() is the [[Jacobi's elliptic functions|Jacobi elliptic cosine function]].
* K() is a complete [[elliptic integral]] of the first kind.
* <math>L_n(\xi)=R_n(\xi,\xi)</math> is the '''discrimination factor''', equal to the minimum value of the magnitude of <math>R_n(\xi,x)</math> for <math>|x|\ge\xi</math>.

For many cases, in particular for orders of the form ''n'' = 2<sup>''a''</sup>3<sup>''b''</sup> where ''a'' and ''b'' are integers, the elliptic rational functions can be expressed using algebraic functions alone. Elliptic rational functions are closely related to the [[Chebyshev polynomials]]: Just as the circular trigonometric functions are special cases of the Jacobi elliptic functions, so the Chebyshev polynomials are special cases of the elliptic rational functions.

== Expression as a ratio of polynomials ==

For even orders, the elliptic rational functions may be expressed as a ratio of two polynomials, both of order ''n''.

:<math>R_n(\xi,x)=r_0\,\frac{\prod_{i=1}^n (x-x_i)}{\prod_{i=1}^n (x-x_{pi})}</math>      (for n even)

where <math>x_i</math> are the zeroes and <math>x_{pi}</math> are the poles, and <math>r_0</math> is a normalizing constant chosen such that <math>R_n(\xi,1)=1</math>. The above form would be true for even orders as well except that for odd orders, there will be a pole at x=∞ and a zero at x=0 so that the above form must be modified to read:

:<math>R_n(\xi,x)=r_0\,x\,\frac{\prod_{i=1}^{n-1} (x-x_i)}{\prod_{i=1}^{n-1} (x-x_{pi})}</math>      (for n odd)

== Properties==

[[File:Rational Elliptic Function (abs, n=3, x=(0,5)).svg|thumb|right|300 px|Plot of the absolute value of the third order elliptic rational function with ξ=1.4. Note the zero at ''x=0'' and the pole at infinity. Since the function is antisymmetric, it is seen there are three zeroes and three poles. Note also that between the zeroes, the function rises to a value of 1 and between the poles, the function drops to the value of the discrimination factor ''L<sub>n</sub>'']]
[[File:Rational Elliptic Function (abs, n=4, x=(0,5)).svg|thumb|right|300 px|Plot of the absolute value of the fourth order elliptic rational function with ξ=1.4. Since the function is symmetric, it is seen that there are four zeroes and four poles. Note again that between the zeroes, the function rises to a value of 1 and between the poles, the function drops to the value of the discrimination factor ''L<sub>n</sub>'']]
[[File:Rational Elliptic Functions (xi varied, x=(-1,1)).svg|thumb|right|300 px|Plot of the effect of the selectivity factor ξ. The fourth order elliptic rational function is shown with values of ξ varying from nearly unity to infinity. The black curve, corresponding to ξ=∞ is the [[Chebyshev polynomial]] of order 4. The closer the selectivity factor is to unity, the steeper will be the slope at in the transition region between x=1 and x=ξ.]]

=== The canonical properties  ===

* <math>R_n^2(\xi,x)\le 1</math> for <math>|x|\le 1\,</math>
* <math>R_n^2(\xi,x)= 1</math> at <math>|x|= 1\,</math>
* <math>R_n^2(\xi,-x)=R_n^2(\xi,x)</math>
* <math>R_n^2(\xi,x)>1</math> for <math>x>1\,</math>
* The slope at x=1 is as large as possible
* The slope at x=1 is larger than the corresponding slope of the Chebyshev polynomial of the same order.

The only rational function satisfying the above properties is the elliptic rational function {{harv|Lutovac|2001|loc=§ 13.2}}. The following properties are derived:

=== Normalization ===

The elliptic rational function is normalized to unity at x=1:

:<math>R_n(\xi,1)=1\,</math>

===Nesting property===

The nesting property is written:

:<math>R_m(R_n(\xi,\xi),R_n(\xi,x))=R_{m\cdot n}(\xi,x)\,</math>

This is a very important property:

* If <math>R_n</math> is  known for all prime ''n'', then nesting property gives <math>R_n</math> for all ''n''. In particular, since <math>R_2</math> and <math>R_3</math> can be expressed in closed form without explicit use of the Jacobi elliptic functions, then all <math>R_n</math> for ''n'' of the form <math>n=2^a3^b</math> can be so expressed.
* It follows that if the zeroes of <math>R_n</math> for prime ''n'' are known, the zeros of all <math>R_n</math> can be found. Using the inversion relationship (see below), the poles can also be found.
* The nesting property implies the nesting property of the discrimination factor:

::<math>L_{m\cdot n}(\xi)=L_m(L_n(\xi))</math>

=== Limiting values ===

The elliptic rational functions are related to the Chebyshev polynomials of the first kind <math>T_n(x)</math> by:

:<math>\lim_{\xi=\rightarrow\,\infty}R_n(\xi,x)=T_n(x)\,</math>

===Symmetry===

:<math>R_n(\xi,-x)=R_n(\xi,x)\,</math> for n even
:<math>R_n(\xi,-x)=-R_n(\xi,x)\,</math> for n odd

===Equiripple===

<math>R_n(\xi,x)</math> has equal ripple of <math>\pm 1</math> in the interval <math>-1\le x\le 1</math>. By the inversion relationship (see below), it follows that <math>1/R_n(\xi,x)</math> has equiripple in <math>-1/\xi \le x\le 1/\xi</math> of <math>\pm 1/L_n(\xi)</math>.

===Inversion relationship===

The following inversion relationship holds:

:<math>R_n(\xi,\xi/x)=\frac{R_n(\xi,\xi)}{R_n(\xi,x)}\,</math>

This implies that poles and zeroes come in pairs such that

:<math>x_{pi}x_{zi}=\xi\,</math>

Odd order functions will have a zero at ''x=0'' and a corresponding pole at infinity.

=== Poles and Zeroes ===
The zeroes of the elliptic rational function of order ''n'' will be written <math>x_{ni}(\xi)</math> or <math>x_{ni}</math> when <math>\xi</math> is implicitly known.    The zeroes of the elliptic rational function will be the zeroes of the polynomial in the numerator of the function.

The following derivation of the zeroes of the elliptic rational function is analogous to that of determining the zeroes of the [[Chebyshev polynomials]] {{harv|Lutovac|2001|loc=§ 12.6}}. Using the fact that for any ''z''

:<math>\mathrm{cd}\left((2m-1)K\left(1/z\right),\frac{1}{z}\right)=0\,</math>

the defining equation for the elliptic rational functions implies that

:<math>n \frac{K(1/L_n)}{K(1/\xi)}\mathrm{cd}^{-1}(x_m,1/\xi)=(2m-1)K(1/L_n)</math>

so that the zeroes are given by

:<math>x_m=\mathrm{cd}\left(K(1/\xi)\,\frac{2m-1}{n},\frac{1}{\xi}\right).</math>

Using the inversion relationship, the poles may then be calculated.

From the nesting property, if the zeroes of <math>R_m</math> and <math>R_n</math> can be algebraically expressed (i.e. without the need for calculating the Jacobi ellipse functions) then the zeroes of <math>R_{m\cdot n}</math> can be algebraically expressed.  In particular, the zeroes of elliptic rational functions of order <math>2^i3^j</math> may be algebraically expressed {{harv|Lutovac|2001|loc=§ 12.9, 13.9}}. For example, we can find the zeroes of <math>R_8(\xi,x)</math> as follows: Define

:<math>
X_n\equiv R_n(\xi,x)\qquad 
L_n\equiv R_n(\xi,\xi)\qquad 
t_n\equiv \sqrt{1-1/L_n^2}.</math>

Then, from the nesting property and knowing that

:<math>R_2(\xi,x)=\frac{(t+1)x^2-1}{(t-1)x^2+1}</math>

where <math>t\equiv \sqrt{1-1/\xi^2}</math> we have:

:<math>
L_2=\frac{1+t}{1-t},\qquad 
L_4=\frac{1+t_2}{1-t_2},\qquad 
L_8=\frac{1+t_4}{1-t_4}
</math>

:<math>
X_2=\frac{(t+1)x^2    -1}{(t-1)x^2    +1},\qquad 
X_4=\frac{(t_2+1)X_2^2-1}{(t_2-1)X_2^2+1},\qquad 
X_8=\frac{(t_4+1)X_4^2-1}{(t_4-1)X_4^2+1}.
</math>

These last three equations may be inverted:

:<math>
x  =\frac{1}{\pm\sqrt{1+t  \,\left(\frac{1-X_2}{1+X_2}\right)}},\qquad
X_2=\frac{1}{\pm\sqrt{1+t_2\,\left(\frac{1-X_4}{1+X_4}\right)}},\qquad
X_4=\frac{1}{\pm\sqrt{1+t_4\,\left(\frac{1-X_8}{1+X_8}\right)}}.\qquad
</math>

To calculate the zeroes of <math>R_8(\xi,x)</math> we set <math>X_8=0</math> in the third equation, calculate the two values of <math>X_4</math>, then use these values of <math>X_4</math> in the second equation to calculate four values of <math>X_2</math> and finally, use these values in the first equation to calculate the eight zeroes of <math>R_8(\xi,x)</math>. (The <math>t_n</math> are calculated by a similar recursion.) Again, using the inversion relationship, these zeroes can be used to calculate the poles.

== Particular values ==

We may write the first few elliptic rational functions as:

:<math>R_1(\xi,x)=x\,</math>
:<math>R_2(\xi,x)=\frac{(t+1)x^2-1}{(t-1)x^2+1}</math>
::: where
:::<math>t \equiv \sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\xi^2}}</math>
:<math>R_3(\xi,x)=x\,\frac{(1-x_p^2)(x^2-x_z^2)}{(1-x_z^2)(x^2-x_p^2)}</math>
::: where
:::<math>G\equiv\sqrt{4\xi^2+(4\xi^2(\xi^2\!-\!1))^{2/3}}</math>
:::<math>x_p^2\equiv\frac{2\xi^2\sqrt{G}}{\sqrt{8\xi^2(\xi^2\!+\!1)+12G\xi^2-G^3}-\sqrt{G^3}}</math>
:::<math>x_z^2=\xi^2/x_p^2</math>
:<math>R_4(\xi,x)=R_2(R_2(\xi,\xi),R_2(\xi,x))=\frac
{(1+t)(1+\sqrt{t})^2x^4-2(1+t)(1+\sqrt{t})x^2+1}
{(1+t)(1-\sqrt{t})^2x^4-2(1+t)(1-\sqrt{t})x^2+1}
</math>
:<math>R_6(\xi,x)=R_3(R_2(\xi,\xi),R_2(\xi,x))\,</math> etc.

See {{harvtxt|Lutovac|2001|loc=§ 13}} for further explicit expressions of order ''n=5'' and <math>n=2^i\,3^j</math>.

The corresponding discrimination factors are:

:<math>L_1(\xi)=\xi\,</math>
:<math>L_2(\xi)=\frac{1+t}{1-t}=\left(\xi+\sqrt{\xi^2-1}\right)^2</math>
:<math>L_3(\xi)=\xi^3\left(\frac{1-x_p^2}{\xi^2-x_p^2}\right)^2</math>
:<math>L_4(\xi)=\left(\sqrt{\xi}+(\xi^2-1)^{1/4}\right)^4\left(\xi+\sqrt{\xi^2-1}\right)^2</math>
:<math>L_6(\xi)=L_3(L_2(\xi))\,</math> etc.

The corresponding zeroes are <math>x_{nj}</math> where ''n'' is the order and ''j'' is the number of the zero. There will be a total of ''n'' zeroes for each order.

:<math>x_{11}=0\,</math>

:<math>x_{21}=\xi\sqrt{1-t}\,</math>
:<math>x_{22}=-x_{21}\,</math>

:<math>x_{31}=x_z\,</math>
:<math>x_{32}=0\,</math>
:<math>x_{33}=-x_{31}\,</math>

:<math>x_{41}=\xi\sqrt{\left(1-\sqrt{t}\right)\left(1+t-\sqrt{t(t+1)}\right)}\,</math>
:<math>x_{42}=\xi\sqrt{\left(1-\sqrt{t}\right)\left(1+t+\sqrt{t(t+1)}\right)}\,</math>
:<math>x_{43}=-x_{42}\,</math>
:<math>x_{44}=-x_{41}\,</math>

From the inversion relationship, the corresponding poles <math>x_{p,ni}</math> may be found by <math>x_{p,ni}=\xi/(x_{ni})</math>
